doc.title: China Industrial Tech: Battery equipment
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/2Q25 slight miss; order recovery but sustainability key; early stage for SS battery; Neutral on Lead_Hangke_2025-09-01

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: We summarize key takeaways from our battery equipment sub- sector's 1H25 results:

Domestic lithium battery demand clearly improved in 1H25 while Lead Intelligent/Hangke new orders trend saw bifurcation as Lead's 1H25 new orders came at Rmb12.4bn, \(+70\%\) yoy, while Hangke's 8M25 new orders recorded Rmb2.7- 2.9bn, \(- 29\% \sim - 24\%\) yoy. The difference between the two companies' order trend is mainly because 1) both Lead/Hangke won large- scale orders at c.Rmb2bn/1.9bn from Volkswagen PowerCo SE in August 2024, resulting in a higher base in 8M24 for Hangke; 2) different customer mix in domestic lithium battery market as Lead has more exposure to domestic Tier- 1 OEMs. Per both companies' mgmt., domestic battery demand recorded clear recovery in 1H25 with battery OEMs' expanding new capacities and improving utilization. Lead intelligent's domestic new orders were \(+120\% \sim +150\%\) in 1H25. According to Lead, the company's current order backlog can support topline growth for 2026E. Both names also have high hopes for the 2H25E overseas order trend as 1) Lead Intelligent targets to improve market share in overseas battery OEMs and explore potential customers in ASEAN, Japan and Korea; 2) Hangke has entered Toyota and Tesla battery supply chains and expects large- scale new orders in the US from LG to fall in 2H25E.

For Lead/Hangke, operating cash flow improved significantly from Rmb2.4bn/541mn in 1H25 vs. Rmb- 1.8bn/Rmb112mn in 1H24. A/R days also decreased from 303/199 days in 1H24 to 253/153 days in 1H25 for Lead/Hangke.

Solid state battery technology still await breakthroughs in the testing pilot lines: Lead/Hangke, received Rmb400- 500mn/50- 100mn FSS battery equipment new orders. Current solid state battery orders are mainly contributed by overseas batteries OEMs seeking technology overtake vs. China domestic OEMs. This could be an early start of the lab- to- factory process but the revenue contribution remain tiny in the near- term. Lead has completed a full- line solution delivery for solid state batteries but all other orders for both companies were equipment- only, indicating most battery OEMs have not finalized their solid state technology, in our view.

Goldman Sachs does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html. Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA in the U.S.

Lead Intelligent (300450. SZ)Lead Intelligent 1H25 revenue/net income came in at Rmb6,610mn/740mn (+15%/61% yoy), - 6%/- 7% vs. GSe. 2Q25 revenue/EBIT/net income were Rmb3,512mn/413mn/375mn (+44%/+487%/n.m. yoy), slightly missing at - 10%/- 28%/- 13% vs. GSe. 2Q25 GP/OP/NP margins reached 33%/12%/11%, - 3pp/+9pp/+15pp yoy and - 2pp/- 3pp/0pp vs. GSe.

Despite the mixed margin trend, the company saw a significant rebound in new orders, with 1H25 new orders reaching Rmb12.4bn (+70% yoy) and 2Q25 new orders at Rmb6.5bn primarily driven by accelerated order placement from domestic clients, whose orders surged by 120- 150% yoy, indicating that full- year new orders are likely to exceed the year- beginning Rmb23bn target. Furthermore, the company's cash flow saw substantial improvement, with 1H25 operating cash flow (OCF) surging to Rmb2.4bn (vs. - Rmb1.8bn in 1H24). Impairment pressure also eased in 1H25 with a Rmb130mn bad debt reversal, reflecting improving customer cash collections.

The 1H25 GPM declines 3pp to \(33.8\%\) , primarily because revenues recognized during this period were from the industry's 2024 trough. Overseas orders maintained a robust GPM of \(40.27\%\) in 1H25.

Increasing pilot line testing equipment orders in solid- state battery industry but far from mass production: the company achieved its first full- line shipment (link) and secured Rmb400- 500mn in orders in 1H25 (vs. Rmb100mn in FY24). Lead Intelligent stands out as the only company capable of providing full solid- state production lines, encompassing critical equipment like dry electrode and isostatic pressing. However, we see the solid- state market is still in its early stages, with all other orders being MW- level equipment- only orders.

Looking ahead, the battery industry has shown clear signs of bottoming out with major clients' CAPEX significantly increasing and utilization continuously improving. Lead Intelligent's domestic order backlog can support topline growth for 2026E. The company anticipates significant new orders from top domestic clients in 2H25E, alongside continued expansion in overseas markets (currently 10% pure overseas market share) including ASEAN, Japan, and Korea.
Exhibit 1: Lead Intelligent 2025 results summary
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Hangke's 1H25 results, with revenue/net income at Rmb1,970mn/288mn (+4%/+7% yoy) and 2Q25 revenue/EBIT/net income at Rmb1,290mn/150mn/172mn (+28%/+21%/+79% yoy), came in slightly below GSe expectations (- 3%/- 1% for 1H25, - 5%/- 27%/- 1% for 2Q25).

Hangke 8M25 new orders recorded Rmb2.7- 2.9bn, representing - 28% - - 24% yoy. This was primarily attributed to a high base from the Rmb1.9bn Volkswagen PowerCo order in August 2024. Excluding this, Hangke's new orders were largely stable with Rmb1.6- 1.7bn from domestic clients and Rmb1.1- 1.2bn from overseas.

Market dynamics on Hangke's side are the acceleration of ESS and mini steel shell batteries for consumer electronics, with the company anticipating potential \(100\%\) growth for both in 2025E. Hangke's confidence in its Rmb6bn full- year new order target is also underpinned by its aggressive overseas expansion. Hangke started operations at its second- phase factory in Korea, positioned to enhance delivery capabilities for Japanese, Korean, and North American clients. The company also has gained entry into new client supply chains such as Toyota and Tesla, while deepening cooperation with existing Korean clients like LG, SK, and Samsung. Management notes a stable GPM from overseas, in contrast with the highly competitive and lower- margin domestic lithium battery equipment market. For 2H25, approximately \(50\%\) of new orders are expected from overseas clients (e.g. LG, Samsung, Toyota, etc.) and \(50\%\) from domestic clients (e.g. Xiamen Hithium, Gotion, etc.).

In the solid- state battery sector, Hangke expects Rmb50- 100mn in orders for 2025, with its current offerings of isostatic pressing, high- pressure formation/capacity equipment. Per mgmt., the industry is still in the R&D to early- production experimental phase.
Exhibit 2: Hangke 2025 results summary
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

For Lead Intelligent, we revise up our 2025E- 30E EPS by \(+0\% \sim +13\%\) to reflect company's ytd order trend and revenue recognition outlook into 2026E. Accordingly, our 12m TP moves to Rmb21.1 (vs. Rmb18.7 previously), still based on 2026E P/E of 15x. Maintain Neutral.

For Hangke, we fine tune our 2025E- 30E EPS by \(1\% \sim 3\%\) on 2Q25 results, order trend outlook and overseas expansion progress. Accordingly, our 12m TP moves to Rmb17.1 (vs. Rmb17.0 previously), still based on 2026E P/E of 15x. Maintain Neutral.

Lead Intelligent is a world- leading manufacturer of battery equipment, focusing on the end markets of lithium- ion batteries, solar photovoltaic, 3C, warehouse & logistics systems, automobile, and fuel cells. Lead Intelligent has \(70\%\) exposure to battery capital expenditure with a balanced customer profile. The company holds a significant market position, with a \(c.25\%\) global market share in lithium- ion battery intelligent equipment. However, we expect global battery equipment TAM to see a deceleration in growth driven by domestic battery oversupply and overseas scaling back expansion targets. Despite some incremental contribution from ESS, we believe second derivative capex addition could decelerate more than end- demand after two years of aggressive capacity expansion from battery OEMs in 2021/22. In the new all solid- state battery sector, Lead Intelligent is the pioneer delivering the first full- line solution. However, we believe all solid- state battery is still in early stage with minor revenue contribution. As a result, we see the battery equipment sub- sector as unfavorable and expect subsequent compression in valuation multiples. We also factor in ongoing account receivables risk referencing the 2019- 20 period (P&L lagging new orders during the 2018- 19 downturn by c.12 months), where Lead Intelligent recorded \(25\%\) impairment loss (as \(0\%\) of operating profit) considering slower EV growth and higher margin pressure due to competition. We view the stock's current valuation as fair vs. our revenue/net income estimates over 2025E- 30E. Hence, we are Neutral rated.
Hangke is a battery equipment manufacturer mainly focused on the core back- end battery manufacturing process (i.e., formation, grading, and testing), with more than 20

years of experience in battery charging and discharging technology, which plays a fundamental role in back- end procedures. We like Hangke as one of a few domestic back- end battery manufacturing equipment providers that can supply complete sets of core back- end equipment to both leading domestic and overseas lithium- ion battery manufacturers. We expect deceleration in growth driven by domestic battery oversupply and overseas scaling back expansion targets. We also think overseas battery equipment TAM has more sustainable growth mainly due to domestic expansion slowing down and varied expansion timelines in different overseas regions aggregating to a smooth growth curve. We believe Hangke is better positioned than any, domestic battery equipment players with the advantage of high orders contribution from overseas, and improving overseas market share. But despite the above stabilizing effect on Hangke, we believe second derivative capex addition will continue to decelerate more than end- demand after two years of aggressive capacity expansion from battery OEMs in 2021/22. Overall, we view the stock valuation as fair vs. our revenue/net income estimates over 2025E305E. Hence, we are Neutral rated.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.
